newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Germany loses initial court battle in deposits row.
newsitem.headline: Germany loses initial court battle in deposits row.

text.p: European Court of Justice advocate-general Philippe Leger has rejected Germany's attempt to outlaw the deposits guarantee directive 94/19/EC, a Court official said on Wednesday.

If the court follows the advocate-general's opinion, which it generally does, it would clear the way for final agreement on a similar draft directive to protect small investors when an investment firm goes bankrupt.

Germany took the Council and the European Parliament to court in 1995 for adopting, against its will, a directive which provides minimum compensation of 20,000 Ecus for bank deposits when a failed firm's assets are not sufficient to cover its liabilities.

The German government argued in court that this was a question of subsidiarity, but the advocate-general stated that the subsidiarity principle should be better defined to avoid other legal disputes, the official said.

Germany particularly contested provisions banning German banks from exporting their generous protection schemes to other EU markets. It also opposed the so-called topping-up clause which allows branches of other EU banks in Germany to join the local guarantee scheme.

The draft directive on investor compensation schemes, COM(96)169, is ripe for final agreement between parliament and Council. A conciliation committee on the legislation is scheduled to meet on December 18.
The court ruling is expected within the next three months, the court official said.
